p: A rural hospital/ hypnoserie outbreak would be plausible if, in such a rural facility, the frequency of boiling or rinsing of syringes was low, and the injection intensity was much higher than the average for HAT ( Table 2). The probability of such conditions would have been higher after the early 1930s for several reasons: (1) the first systematic HAT, syphilis, and yaws campaigns started in 1932 in southeast Cameroon, and in 1930 in the Nola sector ( Table 3; Section 2.4.5); (2) before that, intravenous drugs such as tryparsamide were less commonly used (subcutaneous/intramuscular atoxyl predominated). Thus, the parenteral risks in the region of study strongly intensified after 1930–32 ( Section 2.4.5). If HIV-1 had spread intensively in rural areas by unsterile injections in the 1930s, it would likely have continued to do so in the 1940s and 1950s, when injection intensity was higher ( Figure 2). One would expect the postulated thousands of people so infected [ 17, 18, 35] to have maintained this rural HIV-1 focus in the region for decades. However, the several serological surveys that were made in the area in the period 1975–1992 found zero prevalence until 1987, when HIV-1 arrived there with the pandemic wave (reviewed in [ 38]).
